description: From Medieval Latin infallibilis, from Latin in- + fallibilis. Compare French infaillible. Surface analysis in- +â€Ž fallible.

adjectives.description: infallible (comparative more infallible, superlative most infallible)

entries.meaning: Without fault or weakness; incapable of error or fallacy.
examples: He knows about many things, but even he is not infallible.

entries.meaning: Certain to produce the intended effect, sure.
examples: Try this infallible cure for hiccups.

entries.meaning: A person who, or an object or process that, is taken as being infallible.
